poem:
Title: "The Cry from Chawton"

A chair sits vacant. Paper
holds secrets, muddled by
the hurry of an elder hand.

In the thatched house of
Austen's legacy, a plea
echoes, hanging in the morning stillness.

The world, a ready ear,
leans in to listen. Crafted words –
hard penned, now faded.

Transcribe! A pastiche
of her life unwrapped, old
gems to see the light.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Jane Austen museum appeals to public for help deciphering brother’s memoir There may be gems about Jane Austen’s life and times buried in a memoir handwritten by her older brother – but it is proving difficult to decipher his tricky handwriting. So museum curators at her old cottage in the Hampshire village of Chawton are asking Austen enthusiasts across the world if they can help transcribe the newly acquired 78-page document. The head of collections,". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: Jane Austen museum appeals to public for help deciphering brother’s memoir There may be gems about Jane Austen’s life and times buried in a memoir handwritten by her older brother – but it is proving difficult to decipher his tricky handwriting. So museum curators at her old cottage in the Hampshire village of Chawton are asking Austen enthusiasts across the world if they can help transcribe the newly acquired 78-page document. The head of collections,
